newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: GOLF-CAMPBELL ADMITS TO NOT TRYING.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-CAMPBELL ADMITS TO NOT TRYING.

text.p: In a remarkable confession for a professional sportsman, New Zealand golfer Michael Campbell on Friday admitted to deliberately not trying in a European PGA Tour event last year.
Campbell said he lost his European card for 1997 because he missed some putts on purpose after a prolonged run of poor form left him in despair.

"I missed out on my card by two or three thousand pounds. If I had made the cut when I purposely three-putted, I could have made my card for this year," said Campbell, speaking during the Heineken Classic tournament after shooting a second round 68 for a share of fourth place.
He said the low point in his despair came during a tournament in Spain.
"I was missing cuts on purpose. I had a 20-foot putt on the last hole and I...three-putted on purpose (to miss the cut) because I didn't want to be there," he said.
"It was very, very stupid of me to do that because I was chucking in the towel all the time. I feel that this year is going to be a very good one for me.
"I was very pessimistic about my ability," said Campbell, who finished third in the 1995 British Open, the highlight of an outstanding season in Europe before a wrist injury led to a form slump.
Asked where the incident occured, Campbell said: "My mind was so fogged up. I think it was somewhere in Spain, maybe the Spanish Open. I'm not quite sure.
"I was probably going to give the game up and do something else, like work as a barman... deep down inside, I was pretty close to quitting.
Campbell said he took two months off to consider his future.
"In 1995 life was so easy. Then you go through hard times like I did in '96.

"Firstly, it was my wrist. I had two months not practicing, came out with a new swing and it didn't work. When you are desperate, you listen to everybody's advice. I became so confused and had no idea of where the ball was going.
"I was so wretched. Every time I was over the ball and hit a shot, I was stiff because I was thinking about my backswing, my posture, my alignment, my grip, my follow through, my stance, everything.
Director of Tour Operations for the European PGA Tour John Paramor described Campbell's actions as unfortunate and unprofessional.
"It is the first time in my 22 years on tour that I have heard anything like it. It is an unfortunate incident.
"I am going to speak to Michael at some stage just to find out what it is all about because I am interested.
"It is unfortunate because it is an unprofessional thing to do. The professional approach is to always give your best whatever the circumstances and whatever your score.
"Michael went through some pretty dire times last year and people do some very strange things when they are under stress like that.
"His public scores were there for the record and you do notice when a player is fifth on the order of merit one year and then struggles badly the next.
"I did start to wonder why this was happening to him but players do not usually share their personal turmoil with us," he said.
